title: Christine Christian and Elana Rubin bank on Eastbourne
text:
We return to ME Bank, which only recently announced a tactical retreat from the credit card market due to its “significant disruption” by “schemes like Afterpay”, and on whose board sits Afterpay chairman Elana Rubin! Note also that Rubin did not recuse herself from that strategic decision. What about that?

And while Rubin’s directorship of Mirvac enabled her to buy an apartment in its Eastbourne development on Melbourne’s Fitzroy Gardens before the general public got a look-in, it turns out she wasn’t the only member of ME Bank’s board to do so.

Mirvac directors Elana Rubin and Christine Christian were able to buy apartments in its Eastbourne development before the general public got a look-in Supplied

Two months after Rubin slapped down her deposit on a $1.89 million flat in the prestigious Albert Street sanctuary in May 2016, her fellow ME director Christine Christian did the same, but on one going for $2.99 million. That joint must be rather liveable.

Christian, a former CEO of debt collector Dun & Bradstreet and now deputy chair of FlexiGroup, purchased her property through Molly Bloom Investments Pty Ltd, of which she is sole shareholder.

Christine Christian: a presumed fan of Ulysses. Arsineh Houspian

It’s an interesting name for a personal holding company, but certainly in character (pun intended). Because Christian (AKA Repo Woman?) is also a director of the State Library of Victoria and Molly Bloom was of course a character in James Joyce’s literary masterpiece, Ulysses. Indeed, the novel – unlike ME board meetings, we trust – ends with her stream-of-consciousness soliloquy.

Unless, of course, Christian is a mad poker player? The real Molly Bloom (born more than 200 years after the fictional opera singer cheated on Leopold with Blazes Boylan) ran high-stakes card games for Hollywood celebrities in Los Angeles and New York, before being swept up in an FBI investigation in 2013. She was played by Jessica Chastain in the 2017 film written by Aaron Sorkin. But we’re going with the Joyce angle. It’s not as if Christian’s on the Village Roadshow board…
description: Mirvac directors Elana Rubin and Christine Christian were able to buy apartments in the company's Eastbourne development before the general public got a look-in
